body.p: To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin Governor of Kentucky:

The undersigned Jurors who tried the Indictment against Maria N. Johnson on a charge of having in her possession counterfeit Gold coin with the intention of circulating the same, at the present term of the Campbell Circuit Court state that the evidence conduced to show her guilt & they were constrained by the law & facts to find a verdict against her & the fixed her punishment at the lowest time the law will allow. They further state that James Johnson whom they believe to be her husband, was at the same time convicted with her as accessory -- that the said Maria N., is an old Woman & has several small children
needing her care & protection especially during the imprisonment of her said Husband & under such circumstances & in view of the further fact that the conviction & the imprisonment of near two months which she has already suffered will tend to reform her course of life they recommend her to Your Excellency as a fit subject for Executive Clemency.

Feby 21. 1862.
Tho McGideon foreman
James
Peter Bean
Francis Null
Jos. H. Peters
Henry Shrimp
Thos Spinks
Geo. Gray
Joseph Eichelberger
W. Taner
Jordan Noe
Jos A. Piner
We recommend the foregoing.
R. H. Caldwell Banker & witness
J. K. Stone witness
Jas Johnson Clk
H D John Comr C C A
James T. Berry Jr
Joseph Morlidge
W W Brown witness
H. Line, City Clerk
R D Haysman
C Smithers

M. Cook Dept Sheriff
A D Smalley
Wm H. Bennet M. C. N
who made the arrest

The worries of the Jurors who convicted Mrs Johnson appear in the first column they are all good men. Mrs Johnson is an old woman about 45 years of age & has several small children who need her care no charges have been made against her heretofore The signatures of the jurors are genuine. I join in asking the Executive clemency in her behalf.
I am Satisfied the Commonwealth will not suffer any by releasing the old woman Feby 25th 1862

R T Baker M S
co P Webster
C. Campbell

Issue pardon
B. M
Campbell Cir Ct
M. N. Johnson
Felony
2 yrs. Penty.
Issd Feby 25. 1862
